In an exclusive interview with the BBC, Sunundap Pichai called today's AI moment extraordinary, but also admitted it contains elements of irrationality. That is Silicon Valley code for yes, this is a bubble and yes, it can burst. And when asked if Google would be safe, Pichai didn't hesitate. I think no company is going to be immune, including us. End quote. That is the most direct acknowledgement yet from a big tech CEO that the global AI frenzy may be overheated. And here's where the bubble conversation gets even more interesting. Because while Sundar warns about irrationality in AI investing, Warren Buffett's Bergkshire haway has quietly shifted its bets. Recent regulatory filings show that Berkshire has become trimming its Apple holdings, the stock it once called its crown jewel and increasing its exposure to Alphabet, the parent of Google. You ask why? Here's why. Because Google's AI positioning from Gemini 3 to Tensor chips to search AI mode is now seen as a long-term compounding engine. Clearly Buffett's left tenants are reallocating towards the companies building the infrastructure of the next decade. When even Berkshire moves tells you one thing the AI bubble may burst someday but money is betting that Google survives the aftermath stronger. End quote. So, well, if this is a bubble, it's not slowing down. The technology is transformative. But the investment climate around it is overheated, accelerated and inflated beyond fundamentals. Sundar Pichai's message is quite simple. AI is the new internet. But the bubble around AI is the new.com. And if it bursts, every company from OpenAI to Nvidia to Google will feel the earthquake.
